Auditing of accounts etc
	Duty to appoint auditors
		In each year of account, a registered society must (subject to subsection(2)) appoint one or more qualified auditors to audit its accounts and balancesheet for that year.
		If the society is a small society for the year of account, it must—
			make an appointment under subsection (1) for that year, or
			appoint two or more persons who are not qualified auditors to audit itsaccounts and balance sheet for that year.
		The FCA may give a direction to a society that is a small society for thecurrent year of account, requiring it to make an appointment under subsection(1) for that year.
		For the purposes of this Part a registered society is a “small society” fora year of account if—
			the total amount of its receipts and payments in respect of the precedingyear of account did not exceed £5,000,
			it had no more than 500 members at the end of that year, and
			the total value of its assets at the end of that year did not exceed£5,000.
		The Treasury may by regulations—
			substitute for any sum or number for the time being specified in subsection(4) such other sum or number as the Treasury consider appropriate;
			prescribe what receipts and payments of a society are to be taken intoaccount for the purposes of that subsection.
				The regulations may make different provision for different cases orcircumstances.
		This section is subject to section 84 (power of certain societies todisapply this section).
	Power of certain societies to disapply section 83
		A registered society may by resolution disapply section 83 (duty to appointauditors) in respect of a year of account if—
			the total value of its assets at the end of the preceding year of accountdid not exceed £2,800,000, and
			its turnover for that preceding year did not exceed £5,600,000.
		The resolution must be passed at a general meeting at which—
			less than 20% of the total votes cast are cast against the resolution, and
			less than 10% of the society’s members for the time being entitled underits rules to vote cast their votes against the resolution.
		Subsection (1) does not apply to a society that—
			is a credit union,
			is a subsidiary,
			has a subsidiary,
			holds a deposit or has at any time since the end of the preceding year ofaccount held a deposit (other than a deposit in the form of withdrawable sharecapital), or
			is registered in the register of social landlords maintained under section20(1) of the Housing (Scotland) Act [2010 (asp 17)](/id/asp/2010/17?view=plain"Go to item of legislation").
		The FCA may by notice to a society disapply subsection (1) in relation tothe year of account in which the notice is given.
		A resolution under subsection (1) has no effect if, at any time before theend of the year of account to which it relates—
			the society is within a paragraph of subsection (3), or
			the society is given a notice under subsection (4).
		Subsection (1) applies in relation to a registered society that is acharity or recognised body as if for paragraph (b) there were substituted—
			its gross income for that preceding year did not exceed £250,000.”
		In subsection (6) “recognised body” has the meaning given by article3(6)(c) of the Charities and Trustee Investment (Scotland) Act 2005(Consequential Provisions and Modifications) Order 2006 ([SI2006/242](/id/uksi/2006/242?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")).
		Where a society’s year of account is for a period other than a calendaryear, the figure in subsection (1)(b) (including that provision as it haseffect by virtue of subsection (6)) is to be proportionately adjusted.
	Duty to obtain report in certain cases where section 83 is disapplied
		This section applies to a registered society for a year of account (“theyear”) if—
			section 83 (duty to appoint auditors) does not apply to the society for theyear because of a resolution under section 84 (power to disapply auditingrequirements), and
			the society’s turnover in the preceding year of account exceeded £90,000.
		The society must, within the period of 28 days beginning immediately afterthe end of the year, appoint a qualified auditor to make—
			a report on its accounts and balance sheet for the year which states, inthe auditor’s opinion—
			whether its revenue account, any other account to which the report relates,and balance sheet are in agreement with its books of account kept undersection 75, and
			(on the basis of the information contained in those books of account)whether the revenue account and balance sheet comply with the requirements ofthis Act, and
			a report relating to the preceding year of account which states whether, inthe auditor’s opinion, the financial criteria for the exercise of the powerconferred by section 84 were met in relation to the year.
	Power to require accounts etc for past years to be audited by qualifiedauditor
		The FCA may give a direction under this section to a registered society inrespect of any relevant year.
		A “relevant year”, in relation to a society, is any year of account beforethe current year of account for which—
			the society was a small society and made an appointment under section83(2)(b) (appointment of non-qualified auditors), or
			section 83 did not apply to the society because of a resolution undersection 84 (power to disapply auditing requirements).
		If a direction is given—
			the society must appoint one or more qualified auditors to audit itsaccounts and balance sheet for the relevant year, and
			if the society sent its annual return for the relevant year to the FCAbefore the date of the direction, the society must (after audit, and within 3months from receipt of the direction) send to the FCA a further annual returncomplying with the requirements of this Part (other than as to the time it isgiven).
	Auditors: content of report and powers
		This section applies where a registered society has appointed auditorsunder section 83 for a year of account (“the year”).
		The auditors must make a report to the society on—
			the accounts examined by them, and
			the society’s revenue account and balance sheet for the year.
		The report must state—
			whether, in the auditors’ opinion, the revenue account and balance sheetfor the year give a true and fair view of the matters mentioned in section80(1) to (3);
			whether that revenue account and balance sheet comply with the otherrequirements of this Act;
			if the report relates to any other accounts, whether those accounts give atrue and fair view of any matter to which they relate.
		In preparing the report, the auditors must carry out such investigations aswill enable them to form an opinion as to—
			whether the society has kept proper books of account, and maintained asatisfactory system of control over its transactions, in accordance withsection 75;
			whether the revenue account, any other accounts to which the reportrelates, and the balance sheet are in agreement with the society’s books ofaccount.
		If— 
			the auditors are of opinion that the society has failed to comply withsection 75, or
			the revenue account, any other accounts to which the report relates and thebalance sheet are not in agreement with its books of account,
				this must be stated in the report.
		Each of the auditors—
			has a right of access at all times to the society’s books, deeds andaccounts and to all other documents relating to its affairs, and
			is entitled to require from the society’s officers such information andexplanations as the auditor considers necessary for the performance of theauditors’ duties.
		If the auditors fail to obtain all the information and explanations which,to the best of their knowledge and belief, are necessary for the purposes oftheir audit, this must be stated in the report.
		The auditors are entitled—
			to attend any general meeting of the society;
			to receive all notices of, and other communications relating to, anygeneral meeting which any member of the society is entitled to receive;
			to be heard at any meeting which they attend on any part of the business ofthe meeting which concerns them as auditors.
	Persons appointed under section 82 or 85: powers etc
		This section applies to a person appointed by a registered society—
			for the purposes of making a report of a kind mentioned in any of rows 4 to6 of the table in section 82 (report on interim revenue account or balancesheet), or
			under section 85 (duty to obtain report in certain cases where section 83disapplied).
		For the purposes of the appointment, the person—
			has a right of access at all times to the society’s books, deeds andaccounts and to all other documents relating to its affairs, and
			is entitled to require from the society’s officers such information andexplanations as the person considers necessary.
		If the person fails to obtain all the information and explanations which,to the best of the person’s knowledge and belief, are necessary for thepurposes of doing what the person has been appointed to do, this must bestated in the person’s report.
		The person is entitled—
			to receive notice of, and attend, any general meeting of the society atwhich a relevant matter is discussed, and
			to be heard at any such general meeting which the person attends on anypart of the business of the meeting which relates to a relevant matter.
		In subsection (4) “relevant matter” means—
			any report made by the person, or
			any matter which is relevant to what the person has been appointed to do.

Annual returns
	Annual returns
		A registered society must, within the period of 7 months beginningimmediately after the end of a year of account, send to the FCA—
			a return relating to its affairs for that year (the society’s “annualreturn” for that year),
			a copy of each balance sheet made during that year, and
			a copy of any relevant auditor’s report for that year.
		The annual return—
			must contain the society’s revenue account for that year prepared inaccordance with section 79 and a balance sheet as at the end of that year, and
			may contain other accounts only if they have been reported on under section85(2)(a) or 87.
		“Relevant auditor’s report” means—
			if section 83 (duty to appoint auditors) applies for that year, theauditor’s report on the society’s accounts for that year and any auditor’sreport on a balance sheet made during that year;
			otherwise, any report for that year required by section 85.
		The powers under sections 143 and 144 to determine the form of an annualreturn and the particulars to be contained in annual returns are subject tosubsection (2).
	Duty to provide copy of annual return on demand
		A registered society must give a copy of its latest annual return, free ofcharge, to any member or person interested in the society’s funds who asks forit.
		Where a request under subsection (1) is made, the following must besupplied with the annual return—
			a copy of—
			the auditor’s report on the accounts and balance sheet contained in thereturn, or
			if section 83 (duty to appoint auditors) does not apply to the society forthe year of account to which the annual return relates, any report required bysection 85(2)(a);
			the society’s latest group accounts (if any).
		A society is regarded as having given a person a copy of its latest annualreturn and the documents required by subsection (2) to be supplied with thatreturn (“the relevant documents”) if the following conditions are met—
			the person has agreed (generally or specifically) that the society may makethe relevant documents available to the person on a website (and has notrevoked that agreement);
			the society has notified the person of the following—
			the website address;
			the presence of the documents on the website;
			the place on the website where the documents may be accessed;
			how to access them; and
			the documents are present on the website for the whole of the period—
			beginning with the day the notification under paragraph (b) is sent (or, iflater, the day the documents first appear on the website), and
			ending with the day the annual return ceases to be the society’s latestannual return.
		If any of the documents is absent from the website for part of the periodreferred to in subsection (3)(c), the absence is to be disregarded if it iswholly attributable to circumstances that it would not be reasonable to haveexpected the society to prevent or avoid.

Auditors
	Meaning of “qualified auditor”
		In this Part “qualified auditor” means a person eligible for appointment as astatutory auditor under Part 42 of the Companies Act 2006.
	Persons ineligible for appointment as auditors etc
		This section applies to an appointment by a registered society of a person—
			as auditor of the society,
			for the purposes of making a report of a kind mentioned in row 5 or 6 ofthe table in section 82 (report on interim revenue account or balance sheet),or
			under section 85 (duty to obtain report in certain cases where section 83disapplied).
		None of the following may be appointed—
			an officer or employee of the society or any connected registered society;
			an employee, employer or partner of a person within paragraph (a);
			a person prohibited by section 1214 of the Companies Act 2006 (independencerequirement) from acting as statutory auditor of a company that is asubsidiary of the society.
		For this purpose, a society is “connected with” another society if—
			one of them is a subsidiary of the other, or
			they are both subsidiaries of another registered society.
		An appointment made in contravention of this section is ineffective for thepurposes of this Part.
		For the purposes of subsection (2), a society’s auditor is not to beregarded as an employee of the society (and the auditor is not an “officer” -see section 149).
	Re-appointment and removal of qualified auditors
		A qualified auditor appointed to audit a registered society’s accounts andbalance sheet for the preceding year of account (“the existing auditor”) isre-appointed as the society’s auditor for the current year of account.
			This is subject to the following provisions of this section.
		The existing auditor is not re-appointed if a resolution is passed at ageneral meeting of the society—
			appointing another person instead of the existing auditor,
			providing expressly that the existing auditor is not to be re-appointed, or
			disapplying section 83 (duty to appoint auditors) in relation to thecurrent year of account.
		The existing auditor is not re-appointed if the auditor—
			has given the society notice in writing of the auditor’s unwillingness tobe appointed,
			is ineligible for appointment for the current year of account (seesubsection (5)), or
			has ceased to act as the society’s auditor by reason of incapacity.
		The existing auditor is not automatically re-appointed by virtue ofsubsection (1) if—
			notice is given of a resolution to appoint a person in place of theexisting auditor, and
			the resolution cannot be proceeded with at the meeting—
			because of the death or incapacity of the person, or
			because the person is ineligible for appointment for the current year ofaccount.
		For the purposes of this section a person is ineligible for appointment forthe current year of account if—
			the person’s appointment in relation to the society is prohibited bysection 92, or
			the person is not a qualified auditor at the time when the question of theperson’s appointment falls to be considered, and the society is not a smallsociety in respect of that year.
	Resolutions relating to appointment or removal of auditors
		This section applies to a resolution at a general meeting of a registeredsociety—
			appointing another person as auditor in place of the existing auditor, or
			providing expressly that the existing auditor is not to be re-appointed.
				“The existing auditor” has the same meaning as in section 93.
		The resolution is effective only if notice of the intention to move it isgiven to the society at least 28 days before the meeting.
		Where notice under subsection (2) is given—
			the society must send a copy of the notice to the existing auditor as soonas possible,
			if the society is required by its rules to give notice of the meeting toits members, it must (if it is practicable to do so) give them notice of theresolution at the same time and in the same way as it gives notice of themeeting, and
			if the society does not give notice under paragraph (b), it must give itsmembers notice of the resolution at least 14 days before the meeting by—
			advertisement in a newspaper having an appropriate circulation, or
			in any other way allowed by the society’s rules.
		Where— 
			section 93(4) applies in relation to the resolution (resolution to appointa person in place of the existing auditor cannot be proceeded with), and
			the society’s rules provide that an auditor can be appointed by aresolution passed at a general meeting only if the society is given notice ofthe intended resolution before the meeting,
			a resolution passed at the meeting re-appointing the existing auditor orappointing an auditor in place of that auditor is effective even though noticeof the resolution has not been given.
		Any provision of this section which requires notice to be given to thesociety’s members or confers any right upon a member is to be read, in thecase of a meeting of delegates appointed by members, as requiring the noticeto be given to the delegates or conferring the right upon a delegate.
	Resolutions relating to auditors: auditors’ representations
		This section applies where a registered society has given notice of aresolution to which section 94 (resolutions relating to auditors) applies tothe existing auditor (within the meaning of that section).
		The auditor may—
			at any time before the date of the general meeting, make representations inwriting to the society (not exceeding a reasonable length) with respect to theintended resolution;
			notify the society that the auditor intends to make such representations;
			request that the society’s members are given notice of—
			the auditor’s intention to make representations, or
			any representations made by the auditor and received by the society beforenotice of the intended resolution is given to its members.
		Where the society receives representations or a notification of intendedrepresentations before the date when notice of the intended resolution isrequired by section 94(3) to be given to its members, the society must—
			in any notice of the resolution given to members, state—
			that it has received the representations or notification, and
			that a copy of any representations received by the society before the dateof the general meeting will be given to any member who makes a request forthem before that date, and
			send a copy of any such representations to any member who makes such arequest.
				See section 96 for provisions about providing a copy of the representations byplacing them on a website.
		The auditor may require any representations made by the auditor before thedate of the general meeting to be read out at the meeting.
		This does not affect the auditor’s right to be heard orally.
		But if, on the application of the society or any other person, theappropriate court is satisfied that the rights conferred by this section arebeing abused to secure needless publicity for defamatory matter—
			copies of the representations need not be sent out, and
			the representations need not be read out at the meeting.
		The appropriate court may order the auditor to pay all or part of thesociety’s costs (or, in Scotland, expenses) on an application under thissection, even if the auditor is not a party to the application.
		The “appropriate court” means—
			if the society’s registered office is in Scotland, the Court of Session;
			otherwise, the High Court.
		Any provision of this section which requires notice to be given to thesociety’s members or confers any right upon a member is to be read, in thecase of a meeting of delegates appointed by members, as requiring the noticeto be given to the delegates or conferring the right upon a delegate.
	Section 95: provision of auditor’s representations by making availableon website
		This section applies where a society is required by section 95(3)(b) tosend a person a copy of the representations referred to there.
		The society is regarded as sending the person a copy of a documentcontaining the representations if the following conditions are met—
			the person has agreed (generally or specifically) that the society may makethe document available to the person on a website (and has not revoked thatagreement);
			the society has notified the person of the following—
			the website address;
			the presence of the document on the website;
			the place on the website where the document may be accessed;
			how to access it;
			the document is present on the website for the whole of the period—
			beginning when the notification is sent (or, if later, when the documentfirst appears on the website), and
			ending 28 days after the day the notification is sent (or, if later, theday the document first appears on the website).
		If the document is absent from the website for part of the period referredto in subsection (2)(c), the absence is to be disregarded if it is whollyattributable to circumstances that it would not be reasonable to have expectedthe society to prevent or avoid.
	Remuneration of qualified auditors
		The Treasury may by regulations prescribe the maximum rates of remunerationto be paid by registered societies for—
			the audit of their accounts and balance sheets by qualified auditors;
			the making of a report (a “relevant report”) for the purposes of—
			row 5 or 6 of the table in section 82, or
			section 85(2)(a) or (b) (duty to obtain report in certain cases wheresection 83 disapplied).
		The regulations may make different provision for different cases orcircumstances.
		An auditor or person appointed to make a relevant report—
			must not ask for or receive, and
			is not entitled to receive,
				remuneration in excess of the rate prescribed by the regulations in respect ofthe auditor’s or person’s service.

Group accounts
	Group accounts
		This section applies to a registered society (“the parent society”) whichhas subsidiaries at the end of a year of account (“the relevant year”).
		The society must ensure that accounts (“group accounts”) are prepared forthat year dealing with the state of affairs and income and expenditure of thesociety and its subsidiaries.
		The group accounts must give a true and fair view of the state of affairsand income and expenditure of the society and the subsidiaries dealt with as awhole, so far as concerns members of the society.
		The group accounts must comprise such accounts and contain such particularsas the Treasury may by regulations prescribe.
			The regulations may make different provision for different cases orcircumstances.
		If a subsidiary’s year of account does not coincide with that of the parentsociety, the group accounts must deal with—
			the subsidiary’s state of affairs as at the end of its year of accountending with or last before the end of the relevant year, and
			its income and expenditure for that year of account.
			This is subject to any direction made by the FCA, on the application of theparent society’s committee or with the consent of that committee.
		The parent society must submit the group accounts for the relevant year foraudit to the auditors appointed to audit the society’s accounts and balancesheet for that year.
		The auditors must make a report to the society on the group accounts,stating—
			whether the accounts have been properly prepared in accordance with therequirements of this Part and any regulations made under it;
			whether, in their opinion, the accounts give a true and fair view of thematters mentioned in subsection (3).
		The parent society must send the group accounts and a copy of the auditor’sreport on them to the FCA together with its annual return for the relevantyear.
	Section 98: exceptions
		This section supplements section 98.
		A registered society is not required to prepare group accounts for a yearof account if, at the end of the year, it is the wholly owned subsidiary ofanother body corporate incorporated in Great Britain.
		Group accounts need not deal with a subsidiary if in the opinion of theparent society’s committee, approved by the FCA—
			it is impracticable, or would be of no real value to the society’s members,in view of the insignificant amounts involved,
			it would involve expense or delay out of proportion to the value to thosemembers,
			the result would be misleading, or harmful to the business of the societyor any of its subsidiaries, or
			the business of the society and that of the subsidiary are so differentthat they cannot reasonably be treated as a single undertaking.
		A society is not required to prepare group accounts if, by virtue ofsubsection (3), the accounts would not need to deal with any of the society’ssubsidiaries.
		For the purposes of section 98, no account is to be taken of a subsidiaryin relation to a year of account if—
			by virtue of subsection (3) or this subsection, there was no requirementfor the subsidiary to be dealt with in group accounts of the parent societyfor the previous year of account, and
			the society’s auditors include in the appropriate report, made on or beforethe relevant date, a certificate to the effect that they agree with thesociety’s committee that the following continued to apply throughout the yearof account—
			the reason given by the committee in its last opinion in respect of thesubsidiary to have been approved by the FCA under subsection (3), and
			the grounds given by the committee in that opinion for that reason.
		For the purposes of subsection (5)(b)—
			  * the “appropriate report” is— 
			if the society is under a duty to ensure that group accounts are prepared forthe year of account, the auditor’s report on those accounts;
			otherwise, the auditor’s report under section 87;
				  * the “relevant date” is the last date for making the annual return for the year of account. 
		For the purposes of this section a registered society is a “wholly ownedsubsidiary” of another body corporate if each of its members is—
			that other body corporate,
			a wholly owned subsidiary of that body, or
			a nominee of that body or such a subsidiary.
		If the society is a PRA-authorised person, the FCA must not give anapproval under this section unless it has consulted the PRA.

Interpretation of Part 7
	Meaning of company being a “subsidiary” of a society
		For the purposes of this Part, a company is a subsidiary of a registeredsociety if—
			the society is a member of the company and controls the composition of itsboard of directors, or
			the society holds more than half in nominal value of the company’s equityshare capital.
		For this purpose, a society is regarded as controlling the composition of acompany’s board of directors if the society, by exercising a power exercisableby it without the consent or concurrence of any other person, can appoint orremove the holders of all or a majority of the directorships.
		For the purposes of subsection (2), a society is treated as having power toappoint to a directorship if—
			a person can be appointed to it only if the society exercises a power of akind mentioned in that subsection in favour of the person,
			a person’s appointment to it follows necessarily from the person’sappointment as a member of the society’s committee, or
			the directorship is held by the society.
		In determining whether a company is a subsidiary of a registered society—
			any shares held or power exercisable by the society in a fiduciary capacityare treated as not held or exercisable by it;
			subject to paragraphs (c) and (d), any shares held or power exercisable byany person as a nominee for the society are treated as held or exercisable bythe society (but this does not apply where the society is concerned only in afiduciary capacity);
			no account is to be taken of any shares held or power exercisable by anyperson by virtue of the provisions of—
			any debentures of the company, or
			a trust deed for securing any issue of such debentures;
			any shares held or power exercisable by the society or a nominee for thesociety (not being held or exercisable as mentioned in paragraph (c)) aretreated as not held or exercisable by the society if—
			the ordinary business of the society includes the lending of money, and
			the shares are held or power is exercisable by way of security only forthe purposes of a transaction entered into in the ordinary course of thatbusiness.
		For the meaning of “company” and “equity share capital” see section 102.
	Meaning of society being a “subsidiary” of another society
		For the purposes of this Part, a registered society (S) is a “subsidiary”of another registered society (P) if—
			P is a member of S and controls the composition of its committee, or
			P can exercise a majority of the votes to which S’s members are entitledunder its rules.
		For this purpose P is regarded as controlling the composition of S’scommittee if—
			P can appoint and remove all or a majority of the committee’s members, byexercising a power that is exercisable by it without the consent orconcurrence of any other person, or
			P is a member of the committee and, by exercising such a power, can appointand remove the remaining members or such number of members as, together withitself, would constitute a majority.
		For the purposes of subsection (2) P is treated as having power to appointa person to membership of S’s committee if—
			the person can be appointed only if P exercises a power of a kind mentionedin subsection (2)(a) in favour of the person, or
			the person’s appointment follows necessarily from the person’s appointmentas a member of P’s committee.
		Section 100(4) applies (with necessary modifications) for the purposes ofthis section as it applies for the purposes of section 100.
	Interpretation of Part 7
		In this Part—
		  * “company” includes any body corporate other than a registered society; 
		  * “deposit” is to be read with— 
			section 22 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000,
			any relevant order under that section, and
			Schedule 2 to that Act;
				  * “equity share capital”, in relation to a company, means its issued share capital excluding any part of it which (as regards dividends and capital) carries no right to participate beyond a specified amount in a distribution; 
				  * “qualified auditor” has the meaning given by section 91; 
				  * “small society” has the meaning given by section 83; 
				  * “subsidiary” has the meaning given by sections 100 and 101; 
				  * “turnover”, in relation to a society, means the amounts derived from the provision of goods and services falling within the society’s activities after deduction of— 
			trade discounts,
			value added tax, and
			any other taxes based on the amounts so derived.

Part 8Inspection and investigations
	Power to inspect books etc
		Power of members etc to inspect own account and society’s register
			A member of a registered society, and any person having an interest in itsfunds, must be allowed to inspect the following at all reasonable hours—
				the person’s own account, and
				all entries in the society’s duplicate register kept under section 30(register of members and officers) or, if no duplicate register is kept, allentries in its register kept under that section except those made undersection 30(2)(c) and (d) (shares and property of members).
			Subsection (1) is subject to any regulations as to the time and manner ofinspection which may from time to time be made by the society’s generalmeetings.
		Power of society to make rules authorising inspection of books
			A registered society may by its rules authorise the inspection of such ofits books upon such conditions as may be specified in the rules.
			The rules may not authorise a person to inspect another person’s loan ordeposit account without that other person’s written consent.
			Subsection (2) does not apply to inspection by an officer of the society ora person specially authorised by a resolution of the society.
		Power of FCA to appoint accountant or actuary to inspect a society’sbooks
			The FCA may, on the application of at least 10 qualifying members of aregistered society, appoint an accountant or actuary to inspect the society’sbooks and to report on them; but this is subject to subsection (3).
			“Qualifying member” means a person who, immediately before the date of theapplication, has been a member for at least one year.
			The members who make the application must deposit with the FCA as securityfor the costs of the proposed inspection such sum as the FCA may require.
			The expenses of and incidental to the inspection are to be met—
				by the applicants,
				out of the society’s funds, or
				by the society’s members, officers, former members or former officers,
					in such proportions as the FCA directs.
			A person appointed under this section has power to—
				make copies of any of the society’s books, and
				take extracts from those books,
				at all reasonable hours at the society’s registered office or at any otherplace where the books are kept.
			The FCA must communicate the results of any inspection under this sectionto the applicants and the society.
	Inspectors and special meetings
		Appointment of inspectors and calling of special meetings
			The FCA may, on the application of at least 10% of a registered society’smembers or (if less) 100 members—
				appoint one or more inspectors to examine into and report on the society’saffairs, or
				call a special meeting of the society.
			The power of the FCA to call a special meeting under this section in thecase of a relevant society in respect of which a moratorium is in force undersection 1A of the Insolvency Act 1986 is subject to paragraph 12(1)(b) ofSchedule A1 to that Act as applied in relation to a relevant society by anorder under section 118.
			An application under this section must be supported by such evidence forthe purpose of showing that the applicants have good reason for requiring theexamination or meeting (and do not have malicious motives) as the FCA directs.
			The society must be given such notice of the application as the FCAdirects.
			The FCA may require the applicants to give security for the costs of theproposed examination or meeting before exercising its powers under subsection(1).
			The expenses of and incidental or preliminary to an examination or specialmeeting are to be met—
				by the applicants,
				out of the society’s funds, or
				by the society’s members, officers, former members or former officers,
					in such proportions as the FCA directs.
			In this section “relevant society” means a registered society which is not—
				a private registered provider of social housing, or
				registered as a social landlord under Part 1 of the Housing Act 1996 orunder Part 2 of the Housing (Scotland) Act 2010.
		Section 106: examinations and special meetings
			This section supplements section 106.
			An inspector may—
				require the production of any (or all) of the society’s books, accounts,securities and documents;
				examine on oath its officers, members, agents and employees in relation toits business (and may for that purpose administer oaths).
			The FCA may direct—
				the time and place of a special meeting;
				the matters to be discussed and determined at the meeting.
			A special meeting has—
				all the powers of a meeting called in accordance with the society’s rules;
				the power to appoint its own chair (despite anything in the society’srules).
	General restriction on inspection
		General restriction on inspection of books
			Except as provided by this Act, no member or other person has a right toinspect a registered society’s books.

Amalgamations and transfers of engagements between societies
	Amalgamation of societies
		Any two or more registered societies may, by special resolution of each ofthem, become amalgamated together as one society.
		The amalgamation may involve the dissolution, or division of the funds, ofany of the societies.
		On the amalgamation, the property of each of the societies vests in theamalgamated society without the need for any form of conveyance other thanthat contained in the special resolution.
		Section 111 contains provisions about special resolutions under thissection.
		The amalgamation does not prejudice any right of a creditor of any of thesocieties.
	Transfer of engagements between societies
		A registered society (society A) may by special resolution transfer itsengagements to any other registered society which undertakes to fulfil thoseengagements (society B).
		If the resolution approves the transfer of all or part of society A’sproperty to society B, the property vests in society B without any conveyanceor assignment (or, in Scotland, assignation).
		Section 111 contains provisions about special resolutions under thissection.
		The transfer of engagements does not prejudice any right of a creditor ofeither society.
	Special resolutions under section 109 or 110
		This section supplements sections 109 and 110.
		A resolution is a “special resolution” if—
			the resolution is passed at a general meeting by at least two-thirds of theeligible members who vote,
			notice of this meeting (“the first meeting”), specifying the intention topropose the resolution, is duly given in accordance with the society’s rules,
			the resolution is confirmed at a subsequent general meeting by over half ofthe eligible members who vote,
			notice of this meeting (“the second meeting”) is duly given, and
			the second meeting is held at least 14 days, and no more than one month,from the day of the first meeting.
		In subsection (2)—
			“eligible member” means a member entitled under the society’s rules tovote;
			references to voting are to voting in person or, where the rules allowproxies, by proxy.
		At a general meeting such as is mentioned in subsection (2), a declarationby the chair that the resolution has been carried is conclusive evidence ofthat fact.
		Within 14 days from the day the special resolution is confirmed at thesecond meeting, the society must send the FCA a copy of it—
			signed by the chair of the second meeting, and
			countersigned by the society’s secretary.
		The FCA must register the copy of the special resolution received undersubsection (5).
		The special resolution does not take effect until the copy of it has beenregistered.
		Nothing in subsection (5) invalidates registration after the end of the 14days mentioned there.
		If one or more of the societies is a PRA-authorised person, the FCA mustsend a copy of the special resolution to the PRA.

Conversion of society into company etc
	Conversion of society into a company, amalgamation with a company etc
		A registered society may by special resolution determine to—
			convert itself into a company,
			amalgamate with a company, or
			transfer its engagements to a company.
				In this section “company” means a company under the Companies Acts.
		A registered society’s registration under this Act becomes void and(subject to section 126) must be cancelled by the FCA if the society—
			is registered as a company,
			amalgamates with a company, or
			transfers all its engagements to a company.
		Section 113 contains provisions about special resolutions under thissection.
		Section 114 contains further provisions about the conversion of a societyinto a company.
		An amalgamation or transfer of engagements does not prejudice any right ofa creditor of the society.
	Special resolutions under section 112
		This section supplements section 112.
		A resolution is a “special resolution” if—
			the resolution is passed at a general meeting by at least 75% of theeligible members who vote,
			at least 50% of the eligible members vote on the resolution,
			notice of this meeting (“the first meeting”), specifying the intention topropose the resolution, is duly given in accordance with the society’s rules,
			the resolution is confirmed at a subsequent general meeting by over 50% ofthe eligible members who vote,
			notice of this meeting (“the second meeting”) is duly given, and
			the second meeting is held at least 14 days, and no more than one month,from the day of the first meeting.
		In this section—
			“eligible member” means a member entitled under the society’s rules tovote;
			references to voting are to voting in person or, where the rules allowproxies, by proxy.
		At a general meeting such as is mentioned in subsection (2), a declarationby the chair that—
			all reasonably practicable steps have been taken to ascertain the number ofeligible members, and
			the resolution has been carried,
				is conclusive evidence of those facts.
		Within 14 days from the day of the second meeting, the society must sendthe FCA a copy of the special resolution that is—
			signed by the chair of the second meeting, and
			countersigned by the society’s secretary.
		The FCA must register the copy of the special resolution received undersubsection (5).
		The special resolution does not take effect until the copy of it has beenregistered.
		Nothing in subsection (5) invalidates registration after the end of the 14days mentioned there.
		If the society is a PRA-authorised person, the FCA must send a copy of thespecial resolution to the PRA.
	Conversion of society into a company: supplementary
		This section applies in relation to the conversion of a society into acompany under section 112.
		Where— 
			a special resolution for converting a registered society into a companycontains the particulars required by the Companies Acts to be contained in acompany’s memorandum of association, and
			the FCA has registered a copy of it,
				a copy of it under the FCA’s stamp and seal has the same effect as amemorandum of association duly authenticated under the Companies Acts.
		Registration of a registered society as a company does not affect—
			any right or claim for the time being subsisting against the society, or
			any penalty for the time being incurred by the society.
		For the purpose of enforcing any such right, claim or penalty, the societymay be sued and proceeded against in the same way as if it had not becomeregistered as a company.
		Any such right or claim, and the liability to any such penalty, haspriority as against the company’s property over all other rights or claimagainst, or liabilities of, the company.

Conversion of company into society
	Conversion of company into a registered society
		A company registered under the Companies Acts may by special resolutiondetermine to convert itself into a registered society.
		The resolution must—
			be accompanied by a copy of the society’s rules, and
			appoint 3 members of the company (“the appointed members”) to perform thefunctions mentioned in subsections (3) and (4).
		The appointed members and the company’s secretary (or, if it has nosecretary, a director of the company) must sign the rules.
		The resolution must provide either—
			that the appointed members are authorised to accept any alterations to therules made by the FCA without further consulting the company, or
			that the appointed members must lay any such alterations before the companyin general meeting for acceptance.

Dissolution by an instrument of dissolution
	Dissolution of society by an instrument of dissolution
		A registered society may be dissolved by an instrument of dissolution that—
			complies with subsection (2), and
			is approved in a way mentioned in subsection (3).
		The instrument must set out—
			the society’s assets and liabilities in detail;
			the number of members and the nature of their interests in the society;
			any creditors’ claims, and the provision to be made for their payment;
			the intended appropriation or division of the society’s funds and property(unless the instrument states that this is to be left to the award of the FCAor PRA).
		The ways in which the instrument may be approved are as follows—
			by at least 75% of the society’s members consenting to it, that consentbeing testified by their signatures to the instrument;
			in the case of a dormant society that is not a credit union, by a specialresolution of the society;
			in the case of a credit union, by a special resolution of the society thatis confirmed by the appropriate authority.
		An alteration in an instrument of dissolution may be made—
			by the consent of at least 75% of the society’s members, testified by theirsignatures to the alteration, or
			if the instrument was approved by a special resolution of the society, by afurther special resolution.
		Section 120 contains provisions about special resolutions under thissection.
		In subsection (3)(b) “dormant society” means a society—
			whose accounts for the current year of account and the two years of accountpreceding it show no accounting transactions except—
			fees paid to the FCA;
			fees paid to the PRA;
			payments of dividends;
			payments of interest; and
			that has notified the FCA that it is dormant.
		For the purposes of subsection (3)(c) the appropriate authority is treatedas confirming a special resolution unless it notifies the society in writingto the contrary within 21 days of the society sending a copy of the resolutionto it.
	Special resolutions under section 119
		This section supplements section 119.
		A resolution is a “special resolution” if—
			the resolution is passed at a general meeting by at least two-thirds of theeligible members who vote,
			notice of this meeting (“the first meeting”), specifying the intention topropose the resolution, is duly given in accordance with the society’s rules,
			the resolution is confirmed at a subsequent general meeting by over half ofthe eligible members who vote,
			notice of this meeting (“the second meeting”) is duly given, and
			the second meeting is held at least 14 days, and no more than one month,from the day of the first meeting.
		In this section—
			“eligible member” means a member entitled under the society’s rules tovote;
			references to voting are to voting in person or, where the rules allowproxies, by proxy.
	Instruments of dissolution: notification to FCA etc
		This section applies in relation to an instrument of dissolution withinsection 119(1).
		The instrument must be sent to the FCA (and, if the society is a PRA-authorised person, the PRA), accompanied by a statutory declaration that allrelevant provisions of this Act have been complied with.
		The statutory declaration must be made by the society’s secretary and—
			3 members, or
			both members (if the society consists solely of 2 registered societies).
		A copy of any special resolution under section 119—
			signed by the chair of the second meeting, and
			countersigned by the society’s secretary,
				must be sent to the FCA (and, if the society is a PRA-authorised person, thePRA) within the period of 14 days beginning with the day of the secondmeeting.
		The FCA must register the instrument of dissolution (and any alterations toit) in the same way as an amendment of the society’s rules.
		But it must not register it until it has received the society’s annual returnfor its last year of account (see section 77(8) or 78(7)).
		The FCA must register a copy special resolution received under subsection(4) at the same time as it registers the instrument of dissolution (and anyalterations to it).
		The instrument of dissolution (and any alterations to it) are binding onthe society’s members.
		In this section “the second meeting” has the same meaning as in section120.
	Instruments of dissolution: advertisement, dissolution etc
		Where the FCA receives an instrument of dissolution of a society undersection 121, it must ensure that notice of the dissolution is advertised in—
			the Gazette, and
			a newspaper circulating in or about the locality in which the society’sregistered office is situated.
		Subject to subsection (3), the society is dissolved from—
			the date of the advertisement, or
			if later, the date the certificate under section 126 is lodged with theFCA;
				and the requisite consents to, or approval of, the instrument of dissolutionare treated as duly obtained without proof of the signatures to it or of thespecial resolution (as the case may be).
		Subsection (2) does not apply if—
			within the period of 3 months from the date of the Gazette in which theadvertisement appears, a member of the society or a person interested in orhaving a claim on its funds commences proceedings in the appropriate court toset aside the dissolution of the society, and
			the dissolution is accordingly set aside.
		The “appropriate court” means—
			the county court, or
			in Scotland, the sheriff having jurisdiction in the locality in which thesociety’s registered office is situated.
		A person who takes proceedings to set aside the dissolution of a societymust send the FCA (and, if the society is a PRA-authorised person, the PRA)notice of the proceedings—
			within 7 days after the commencement of proceedings, or
			if earlier, by the end of the period mentioned in subsection (3)(a).
		If an order setting aside the dissolution of a society is made, the societymust send the FCA (and, if the society is a PRA-authorised person, the PRA)notice of the order within 7 days after the making of the order.

Part 10Offences
	Offences
		General offences
			A person (whether a registered society, an officer or member of aregistered society, or any other person) commits an offence if the person—
				fails to do anything (including giving a notice or sending a return orother document) that the person is by this Act required to do,
				fails to allow anything to be done that the person is by this Act requiredto allow to be done,
				wilfully neglects or refuses to do any act, or to provide any information,required for the purposes of this Act by the FCA or PRA or by any other personauthorised under this Act,
				does anything forbidden by this Act, or
				makes a return required by this Act, or wilfully provides informationrequired by this Act, that is in any respect false or insufficient.
			A registered society commits an offence if it—
				contravenes, or fails to comply with, any provision of Part 7 exceptsection 77, 78, 81, 89(1) or 90(1), or
				fails to comply with a direction under section 83(3).
			A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summaryconviction to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale.
		Offences by societies to be also offences by officers etc
			Where a registered society commits an offence under this Act, the offenceis treated as also having been committed by—
				every officer of the society who is bound by its rules to fulfil the dutyof which the offence is a breach, or
				if there is no such officer, every member of its committee.
			In proceedings against a person alleged to have committed an offence underthis Act by virtue of subsection (1)(b), it is a defence to prove—
				that the person was ignorant of the commission of the offence, or
				that the person attempted to prevent the commission of the offence.
			Subsection (1) does not apply to an offence under section 127 consisting ofa failure to comply with section 12 or 50(2) or (3).
			For the purposes of this section as it applies in relation to a failure tocomply with section 123(3)(a), a liquidator of a society is treated as anofficer of it.
		Continuing offences
			An act or default constituting an offence under this Act constitutes a newoffence in every week during which it continues.
		Misappropriation of a society’s property etc
			A person who, by false representation or deception, and with fraudulentintent, obtains possession of any property of a registered society commits anoffence.
			A person who has any property of a registered society in the person’spossession commits an offence if, with fraudulent intent, the person—
				withholds or misapplies the property, or
				wilfully applies any part of the property to purposes which are notauthorised by the society’s rules or which are not in accordance with thisAct.
			A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summaryconviction—
				to a fine not exceeding level 2 on the standard scale with costs orexpenses,
				to be ordered to deliver up the property or to repay all moneys improperlyapplied, and
				in default of such delivery or repayment or of the payment of any suchfine, to be imprisoned for a term not exceeding 3 months.
			If in proceedings against a person for an offence under this section it isnot proved that the person acted with fraudulent intent, the person may beordered to deliver up any property belonging to the society or to repay anymoney improperly applied, with costs or expenses.
		Falsification of a society’s records etc
			A person commits an offence if, with intent to falsify a relevant documentor to evade any of the provisions of this Act, the person—
				makes an entry in the relevant document,
				removes or omits anything from the relevant document, or
				orders or allows the making of such an entry or the removal or omission ofanything from the relevant document.
			“Relevant document” means—
				any balance sheet of a registered society,
				any contribution or collecting book of a registered society, or
				any return or document required to be sent, produced or delivered for thepurposes of this Act.
			A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summaryconviction to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale.
	Prosecution of offences
		Prosecution of offences: persons who may bring proceedings and timefor bringing them
			This section applies to proceedings for—
				an offence under this Act that is punishable with a fine, or
				an offence under a registered society’s rules (see section 20).
			The proceedings may be brought by the following—
				in the case of proceedings in respect of an offence under a society’srules, the society;
				in the case of proceedings by virtue of section 127 in respect of neglector a failure to do any act, or provide any information, required by the PRA—
				the FCA (after notifying the PRA), or
				the PRA (after notifying the FCA);
				in the case of proceedings by virtue of any of section 130(1) to (3)—
				the registered society in question,
				any member of that society authorised by the society, the society’scommittee or the FCA, or
				the FCA (except in Scotland);
				in any other case, any person aggrieved or (except in Scotland) the FCA.
			Except in Scotland, no other person may bring proceedings.
			The FCA, the PRA or the Lord Advocate (“the prosecutor”)—
				may (despite any limitation on the time for bringing proceedings containedin any Act) bring proceedings for the offence at any time within one year ofthe discovery of the offence by the prosecutor, but
				may not bring proceedings more than 3 years after the commission of theoffence.
		Prosecution of societies: service of summons etc
			This section applies to proceedings taken against a registered society foran offence under this Act that is punishable with a fine.
			The summons or other process is sufficiently served—
				by leaving a true copy of it at the society’s registered office, or
				if that office is closed, by posting that copy on the outer door of theoffice.

Determination of disputes
	Determination of disputes in accordance with a society’s rules
		If a registered society’s rules give directions as to the way in whichrelevant disputes are to be determined, a relevant dispute is to be determinedin the way directed by the rules (subject to the following provisions of thissection).
		“Relevant dispute” means a dispute between a registered society or anofficer of a registered society and—
			a member,
			a person aggrieved who ceased to be a member not more than 6 monthspreviously (“a relevant former member”),
			a person claiming through a member or relevant former member, or
			a person claiming under the society’s rules.
		Any dispute which would, under the rules, fall to be determined by the FCAor PRA is to be referred to the county court (or, in Scotland, to the sheriff)for determination.
		In England and Wales, any dispute which would, under the rules, be referredto justices is to be determined by a magistrates’ court (subject to subsection(6)).
		In Scotland, any dispute which would, under the rules, be referred tojustices, a justice of the peace court or a court of summary jurisdiction isto be determined by the sheriff.
		If the parties to the dispute consent, the dispute may be determined—
			in England and Wales, by the county court;
			in Scotland, by the sheriff.
		Neither subsection (1) nor the society’s rules prevents a person, inaccordance with the Financial Ombudsman scheme, from having a complaint dealtwith under the scheme before or instead of being determined in the waydirected by the rules.
	Determination of disputes under section 137: application to the court
		This section applies where—
			section 137 applies in relation to a relevant dispute,
			an application is made to the society in question for a reference under itsrules, and
			no determination is made within 40 days after the application is made.
		A person within a paragraph of section 137(2) who is a party to the disputemay apply to the appropriate court, which may hear and determine the matter indispute.
		The appropriate court is—
			in England and Wales, the county court or a magistrates’ court;
			in Scotland, the sheriff.
		“Relevant dispute” has the same meaning as in section 137.
	Determination of disputes otherwise than under a society’s rules
		This section applies in relation to a relevant dispute if the registeredsociety’s rules contain no directions as to the determination of relevantdisputes.
		The dispute may be determined—
			in England and Wales, by the county court;
			in Scotland, by the sheriff.
		Alternatively, in England and Wales, a person within a paragraph of section137(2) who is a party to the dispute may apply to a magistrates’ court, whichmay hear and determine the matter in dispute.
		“Relevant dispute” has the same meaning as in section 137.
	Determination of disputes: supplementary
		Where a determination under section 137(1) is made in a dispute—
			the determination is binding and conclusive on all parties without appeal;
			in England and Wales, the determination is not removable into any court oflaw or restrainable by injunction;
			an application may be made to the county court (or, in Scotland, thesheriff) for enforcement of the determination.
		The county court (or, in Scotland, the sheriff) may order the expenses ofdetermining a dispute under section 137, 138 or 139 to be paid—
			out of the society’s funds, or
			by such parties to the dispute as the court (in Scotland, the sheriff)considers appropriate.
		In England and Wales a magistrates’ court may, for the purposes of thehearing or determination of a dispute under section 137, 138 or 139, granteither party—
			such disclosure as to documents and otherwise, and
			such inspection of documents,
				as it considers necessary for the just and expeditious disposal of thedispute.
		An order under subsection (3) for disclosure to be made on behalf of asociety is to be disclosure by such of its officers as the court maydetermine.
		The court to which a dispute is referred under section 137(3) to (6), 138or 139 may at the request of either party state a case on any question of lawarising in the dispute for the opinion of the High Court or the Court ofSession (as the case may be).

	Channel Islands
		Her Majesty may by Order in Council provide for any provision of this Act,or of any instrument made under it, to extend (with or without modifications)to any of the Channel Islands.
		Any such Order in Council may make such transitional, incidental orsupplementary provision as appears to Her Majesty to be necessary orexpedient.
	Extent 
		Subject as follows, this Act extends to England and Wales and Scotland.
		Chapter 1 of Part 5 extends to England and Wales only.
		Chapter 2 of Part 5 extends to Scotland only.
		The following provisions also extend to Northern Ireland—
			this section;
			sections 136, 147, 154 and 155;
			Schedule 5.
		Any amendment, repeal or revocation made by this Act extends to any part ofthe United Kingdom to which the provision amended, repealed or revokedextends.
		Nothing in this section applies to section 152 (and the repeals made bythis Act do not affect any power by Order in Council to make provisionextending to any of the Channel Islands).
	Commencement 
		This Act comes into force on 1 August 2014, immediately after section 1 of theCo-operative and Community Benefit Societies and Credit Unions Act 2010(registration of societies as co-operative or community benefit societies).
	Short title
		This Act may be cited as the Co-operative and Community Benefit Societies Act2014.
